_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.    FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY

The owners, management, and employees of the Agriform, A Division of The Tremont Group, Inc. (Agriform), Woodland Facility (Facility) at 40189 County Road 18C, Woodland, California, 95776 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.  A detailed Consolidated Emergency Response/Contingency Plan (CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.



2.    FACILITY INFORMATION

The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in Northern California.



Anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia are received, stored, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients.  Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in a 22,440-gallon storage tank (bullet). The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled is 98,040 pounds.  Aqua ammonia is received by truck and stored in a 75,000-gallon storage tank at the site.  The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia handled is 548,625 pounds.    



3.    The Worst-Case Release Scenario and Alternative Release Scenario

The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario were evaluated for each of the regulated processes.  The results of the evaluation are provided in the Risk Management Plan (RMP).



4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.



Safety Information:  Agriform ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances is up-to-date and available for review by employees.  The most recent review of safety

information pertaining to the covered processes took place in May 2015.



Hazard Review:  A hazard review of the regulated processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes.  The most recent update of the hazard review was conducted on June 29, 2015.  Results indicate that no high risk hazards were identified through the hazard review update.



Operating Procedures:  Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are reviewed and revised as needed.  The operating procedures were last reviewed in April 2015.



Training:  The Agriform Facility staff, as well as The Tremont Group, Inc. (Tremont) corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff.  A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program.  The training program was last reviewed in May 2015.  The current training program is comprised of the following:

?    Initial employee training;

?    Periodic refresher training;

?    Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification;

?    Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training; and

?    Training records for each employee.



Maintenance:  The maintenance program at the Facility is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release.  The maintenance program includes equipment inspection, preventative maintenance, recordkeeping, and training.  The latest equipment inspections were conducted in March 2015 and the latest review of maintenance procedures was conducted in January 2015.



Compliance Audits:  Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years.  Records of the audits and follow-up documentation

are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted on May 31, 2013.



Incident Investigation:  An incident investigation program is in place at the Facility and incident investigations would be implemented if needed. 



In addition to the prevention program elements described above, the following chemical-specific prevention steps have been implemented.



Anhydrous Ammonia and Aqua Ammonia:  The Facility implements the provisions of the "Safety Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI); California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Subchapter 1, "Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders"; and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia."



5.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

An incident investigation program is in place at the Facility and incident investigations would be implemented if needed.

 

6.    THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements.  The Consolidated Emergency Response/Contingency Plan (CCP) was most recently updated in June 2015 and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.



7.    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility.  Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, and regulated pesticide processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.
